description:
This place is incredible. I'll admit I was a tiny bit hesitant due to some of the poor quality food pictures on Yelp, but once diving in to our fantastic 10 person Kamayan dinner, I was sold. Everything was cooked to perfection and seemingly easy for them. Both baskets of our food came out within a minute of each other and were filled with seafood, meats, veggies, rice, and sauces. This place popped to the top of my favorite Bay Area restaurants immediately. 

Oh also something that might be helpful- you can get a 2 person Kamayan style dinner. They just bring a smaller basket but there's still a ton of food for two.
author: Scott B.

description:
Yes!! I love this place. +4 1/2 stars.

This is the foundation of great family restaurants. Spots like this make San Francisco beautiful. Some old timers claim the city isn't what it was. Guess what, it still is. Come check it out. This is the city. It's in here.

+ Chicken Adobo - I liked this a lot! Everything browned in oil and I guess a little garlic and then I put it over the great garlic rice, dang, it's awesome. The meat cooked to the point it's falling off the bone and all the other ingredients soaking up the meat flavor. This was a great dish. We'll get this again. 
+ Sisig Baboy - Marinated and Grilled Pork - Excellent! It comes out on a hot skillet so it has a minute to caramelize and just wow. Get this! I was worried that it would be too hot with the peppers but it's not at all too hot. Actually just enough green stuff to mellow out all the fried stuff. The vinegar, soy sauce, and garlic mix are simply amazing. 
+ Lumpiang Shanghai - These are so good they are dangerous. If you get an order, which I highly suggest you do, be careful. They are tasty and crunchy and if dipped in the sauce, sweet and satisfying. With a sip of juice (see below) magic in your mouth! 
+ Calmansi Juice - This is the first time I'd ever had this beverage. They don't have fountain soda so I asked for a house made juice. Before the meal arrived I thought it was too sweet however with dinner it's perfect. 

As we walked out, we thanked them for their great dinner. The reply, "Thank you, tell your friends." I don't know if it was our server or one of the twenty something's that just took a table. That's what I'm doing. Come here. Bring your friends. The Bay area has a huge Filipino population so I'd assume we'd have a lot of great choices - but we don't.  Everybody needs to try this spot at least once. Get in here. The prices are great and food amazing.

You'll see us here again but with our friends next time.

Credit Card welcomed.  They gladly take Visa, MasterCard and Debit. They do not take American Express.
author: Justin S.

description:
A family-run, hole-in-the-wall Filipino restaurant in a quiet corner of the Mission, Pampanguena is the place for a kamayan feast! An order of this comes as a huge spread of food on banana leaves: centered around scoops of white rice are a selection of grilled and fried dishes that are simply delicious. The lumpia were nice and crispy, the preserved egg added a perfect touch of salty flavor, and the grilled squid, chicken, fried fish, and marinated pork were all so flavorful in their own way! The fried shrimp were so crispy that you could just bite right through and eat the shell, and the broccoli, eggplant, and mango/onion/tomato "salsa" were nice and refreshing. On the side came four different types of sauces, and the staff took the time to explain to us which sauces went best with which dishes! In addition to the kamayan, we also had an order of the kare kare, an oxtail peanut-based curry with a bunch of veggies, including Shanghai bok choy, eggplan, and string beans. The curry was thick, gooey, and full of flavor. 

You really can't beat the value for the food you get here. Even though we came close to closing, the staff still took their time to serve us, and I'd definitely recommend a visit!
author: David K.

description: Ordered a tray of lumpia yesterday and although they had a nice crunch, they were practically meatless. I'm disappointed in the inconsistency of their lumpia :( It sucks bc I know their potential... when it's good, it's SO good!
author: ashley l.

description:
Shayla loves food. Shayla loves... Filipino food. And, Shayla loves a Filipino FEAST! And honey, Shayla GOT a Filipino feast at Pampanguena! 

Kamayan style! If you've never had a Kamayan style Filipino feast, then you've been missing out in life. You better prepare those salivary glands for take-off because this is gonna be one delicious @ss flight! This deal is really incredible! A full feast that will happily satisfy at least 6 people for less than $20 bucks a person! You know I'm all in! So, let's break it on down with the list of included food items:

Kamayan Animan (Feeds 6 guests for $68.95):
-Chicken and Pork BBQ
-Grilled tilapia 
-Grilled squid
-Grilled Pork
-Flitter shrimp
-Salted egg 
-Lumpia
-Mango/tomato/onion 
-Sweet yam 
-Steamed white rice 
-Steamed vegetables
-Steamed eggplant 

In addition to this, our party of 8 also ordered:
-Sizzling Sisig baboy (grilled marinated pork)
-Lechon Kawali (crispy fried pork belly)
-Pancit Bihon (stir fried noodles)
-Halo halo

I'm gonna go right ahead and proclaim the sizzling sisig and the crispy lechon as the stars of this show! That sisig came out sizzling and it was sangin' a lullaby to me! It was juicy, flavorful, and marinated to perfection! But that pork belly though! OMG! That lechon was on fiyaaaaahhh! The crispy bake on the outside was PERF! Mixed with the tenderness of the inside... just melting on my tongue like whaaaaa?! You would have thought a girl had died after eatin' that! It was just sooo dayum GOOD! Mmm mmm MMM! 

Moving on to the other standouts: the crispy lumpia, the perfectly grilled tilapia, the fresh mango, tomatoes, and onions, the delightful BBQ chicken, and the perfectly sweet halo halo. I mean, THIS meal was like the meal from God! Somebody please please pleeeaase let THIS meal be my last one on earth because I will gladly accept it in a heartbeat!

If I had to nitpick, I would just say that the salted egg was just a bit too salty for me! I'm also not feeling the fact that this place is cash only, but I digress. Of course I can always say that I would have loved to have more food on the plate because there was NO food left behind here, kids! Portions sizes are ample and the prices are pretty damn cheap for what you get! My friend ordered 100 lumpias for take home for only $30 which is really a steal!

The place is pretty tiny with limited seating for large groups and it's pretty much first come first serve. The service was great and they were able to accommodate all of our picky little needs. They really handled our large group well and cooperated with us. The owner was super sweet and she came out to greet us and to check in on us several times during our stay. All in all, I had a fabulous experience and I cannot wait to dabble in this magnificent feast again!
author: Shayla B.

description:
This place is spacious.

We ordered the family style Kamayan, it was HUGE. We had 6 people eating this thing and still had left over.

They gave so much side sauces. 

They need to add a bit more rice though, they gimped out on the rice -- hello Filipinos need the kanin!!
author: Elijah B.

description:
Kamayan is the traditional Filipino way of eating with your hands, derived from the word "kamay", meaning "hand".

Pampanguena does well to give justice to this way of eating- accommodating large groups if you call ahead, and bringing the vibe of a Filipino family home to a restaurant.

My friends and I (a group of 9) were fine with an order of "animan" (for 6), and added on an order of pancit bihon, sinigang na baboy, and sisig. We chowed down hands first (minus the sinigang soup), and were pretty full afterwards! The animan was definitely enough for a group of 6 or 7, but with a large group, add on to the order!

We were given plate baskets lined with banana leaves, and dipping sauces for the various "ulam" in the kamayan meal. All the grilled meats were so yummy, as well as the lumpia, fish, and squid! The sisig, sinigang, and pancit were also cooked just like it came from mama's or lola's kitchen, so you know the quality of the meals is worth it.

Sarap!!
author: Mary F.

description:
Filipino time was in effect I guess. 

Was here in morning of 4/21/2018 with other customers waiting outside on the street. Yelp time and door sign says opens at 10AM. Yet we got there at 10:15 AM and still closed. Called the phone number and got hung up on. Waited 5 mins to no avail and left. Went to another filipino restaurant instead.
author: Strykher V.

description: As someone who rarely eats Filipino food, Pampanguena quite surprisingly was able to beat my expecations. Came with a group of friends for dinner on Saturday night, and we ordered a huge spread of food for the table. From chicken to lumpia, rice to vegetables, shrimp to fish to salty eggs, this dish was like a treasure box, and we just dug right in. Highlights were definitely the lumpia and shrimp, but everything was very solid and the unique flavors went well together. We also had an order of the oxtail curry which was fantastic -- very rich with good amount of oxtail pieces to share.
author: Alvin W.

description:
FOOD COMA!

I've tried Kamayan style before with friends, but at the wrong place.  I should have come here!  Family-owned small restaurant, always support small businesses.  Doesn't hurt that I also love Filipino food so much.  This place is way better than Pampalasa, I paid over $50 for a Kamayan style dinner at Pampalasa, supporting a friend's last-ditch effort to save an overpriced Filipino restaurant in SOMA.  It was definitely high-end Kamayan feast dinners.  When my Filipino friends told me Pampalasa was overpriced for Kamayan, I knew I had spent way too much $$$ aka sucker!  Needless to say, the restaurant closed.  

Little did I know there's this hidden gem of Filipino cuisine in the Excelsior District!  The staff are super friendly and attentive.  Josie the mom/cook is so awesome.  The ambiance is cozy and small, feels like eating with family once you start grubbin'.

Our Kamayan dinner consisted of the following:

- Lumpias
- Meat
- Shrimp
- Fish
- Calamari
- Salty eggs
- Eggplant
- Rice
- Broccoli
- Mango
- Sweet yams 
 
We ordered a la carte sizzing sisig, lechon, pancit, and halo-halo for dessert.  You know I had to order a tray of lumpias to go for hubby and our growing boy.  They killed the lumpias in the morning LOL!  

Thanks to our friend Hazel C. for organizing this little shindig last minute, as we all fled to the city to beat the heat, but it didn't help...still HOT thanks to the heat wave!  We were all astonished when the bill came out to be $16 per person after all that food.  Keep in mind it's cash only, so bring it; otherwise, there's an ATM inside.  Can't wait for the next get together, let's take over the entire restaurant woo-hoo!!!

'Til we MEAT again (get it) hahaha I crack myself up, see you on Yelp (SYOY)!
author: Christine R.

description:
HOLY MOLY! For my white Midwest (Indiana) husband's birthday, he requested a "boodle fight". He sees it all over our friends & family's social media and was curious. In comes Pampangueña. 

The place is quaint and the decor reminiscent of restaurants from back home; lots of sea creatures and bamboo. We ordered the kamayan for 2 and a BBQ plate for the kids. From the mass of food from photos I've seen, I expected to have to wait a length of time and longingly looked at the food arriving at other tables so I was pleasantly surprised with how quick our order came. The "dalawahan" came with pork & chicken bbq, lumpiang shanghai, fried fish, rice (duh!), itlog na maalat and so very delicious mangoes, tomatoes & onions WITH a side of bagoong served on a banana leaf. It has been a point of conversation between the hubz and I how there is no "fancy" Filipino restaurant because our food isn't about pretty but all about taste. We're "jungle" Asians. Our food is typically served crammed in styro or slopped on a plate. Filipino food served on a banana leaf is possibly the "sexiest" way our food can be plated. Pampangueña hits the mark on making our food pretty AND delicious. 

As food coma was about to set in, our server asked if we were interested in turon or halo halo. Both please. 

After our gluttony had transpired, en route to wash our hands from the kamayan, the owner(?) yells "I JUST MADE SOME FRESH LUMPIA, DO YOU WANT SOME?" ... well sh*t. "Yes ate, I'll take two!" 

TL:DR- Partook in serious feasting and couldn't stop eating. 

We'll definitely be back!
author: Meryl Q.

description:
Meals: I ordered pork BBQ binalot, Laing, grilled squid... They were ok, not great, but just ok. Didn't give me the umph I was hoping for considering I don't get to eat out at Filipino restaurants that much. The halo-halo wasn't bad at all.
The downside: I was sooo hungry my acidity was killing me and when I asked for a simple cup of broth, they couldn't provide it! So forget about flexibility nor customer service, this restaurant doesn't have it. Oh... The son of the owner was trying but the mom, perhaps the owner or manage, didn't have customer service in her DNA.
MORE DOWNSIDE: I understand not accepting Amex for payment. I understand extra charge for using credit card. What I doing understand is not being able to provide an official receipt!!! I asked for one and the mom/manager rudely tells me THAT IS YOUR RECEIPT! uhm.. It was one of those scratch-like sales order... No tax id number whatsoever. So yeah... If they're avoiding to pay taxes, at least I would expect a friendly service. For that, they're very lucky to get at least one star.
author: Abigail E.

description: This has the best garlic fried rice!! I don't like to order it cause it's usually overly seasoned and taste bad but my kids wanted it and I am glad I did. Definitely will be back for that. We ordered the Lechon, chicken Adobo, longanisa with garlic fried rice. We were happy with our food! Will definitely be back.
author: Denise T.

description: We had a great family cousin's lunch here this weekend. Food was delicious and the environment was inviting. We ordered two of the large group lunches, two bangus sisigs, one dinuguan, one lechon kawali, two halo halos, one order of turon, one order of leche flan, and countless sodas.... all for about $250 before tip.  We'll definitely be back!
author: Trish D.

description: I found this place because I wanted to try kamayan style. I've tried eating with my hands many times at my Filipino boyfriend's house, but never at a restaurant and never on banana leaves. It really is so liberating and satisfying! I've been here twice, both times with 5 other people, and ordered the kamayan anima for $68.95. It was a lot of food! I especially loved the grilled tilapia, grilled pork, lumpia, and salsa (mango, tomato, and onion) with rice. The owners are so nice and friendly. Eating here felt like eating at someone's home and we felt very welcome. The sweat yam at the end was also a pleasant surprise. Everything tasted so fresh and natural. My Filipino boyfriend approves as well :)
author: Priscilla L.

description:
The restaurant is in my neighborhood and the people here are so friendly that I hate to givee this place an average review but, really, the food just tastes average to me.   I've gone to this restaurant several times over the years and, except for the turon, have yet to find a dish that I trusty love and crave.  

The kamayan dishes are presented beautifully and are a feast for the eyes but just tastes ok.   Whenever I have a friend that likes to photograph their food, I will usually bring them here because they will usually enjoy the place based on visuals alone despite the so-so taste.  I love their coconut juice which is also beautifully presented.   But, again, I only get these foods for the photographs and not really for the taste. 

Everything else that Ive tried so far is below average.  The making of the halo-halo is usually inconsistent but usually below average.   I once ordered the pork sisig to go and was horribly disappointed since it tasted funny.  I ended up throwing it away, uneaten.  

The only thing that I crave from this restaurant is the turon (fried plantain desert).   The crispy caramelization of the outer wrapping coupled with the sweet plantain inside is just heavenly!   It's usually pre-fried and ready to go near their cash register so makes an easy grab and go dessert.  If you're ever in the mood for something sweet and yummy while in the area, you must drop by and try their plantain.  

Overall, I rate the place as 3 stars since nothing, other than the taste of the turon and the visual appeal of their kamayan dishes and coconut drink, really stands out here.
author: Linda H.

description:
If you like Filipino food, this is the place to go! 

I've been to the Philippines many times. Here in the U.S., it's really difficult to find good Filipino food. There are a lot of options in California, but most are like Panda Express style Filipino food. Barely warm food that has been sitting and is just okay.

This place does it right! Walking in, you immediately get this feeling you just stepped into a Pinoy restaurant.

Videokee - Check!
TFC on the TV - Check! 
Tagalog being spoken all around - Check!
A combo smell of pork, seafood, and fried foods - Check!

The food here is really good, freshly made, and the portions are huge! I love the sisig and BBQ pork! It makes me miss the PH and the people!

On top of that, the staff is really nice...

I also love that they are closing for nearly a month to go on vacation in July! Sign of a true family owned restaurant!
author: Bryan A.

description:
A visit to Pampanguena Cuisine was my first time dining at a legitimate Filipino restaurant and I have to say it was a full-blown success thanks to my fellow Yelpers, some of whom are Filipino and some of whom had tried this type of cuisine known in Philippines as kamayan style which is the traditional Filipino way of eating with your hands and is served on a banana leaf. "Kamay" is the Filipino word for hands and as a foodie who believes the most authentic experience you can have while traveling is to eat like a local and Pampanguena Cuisine is as close as I'm going to get to the Philippines. 

I arrived with a party of eight on a very warm Friday evening to Pampanguena Cuisine on Mission Street in the Excelsior District of San Francisco. These people all very top-notch Yelpers who take their eating and writing about it seriously. We have been wanting to try a traditional Kamayan meal for a long time and now the time was right. They don't take reservations at Pampanguena you just have to wait for a table. After finding out that Pampanguena Cuisine serves a Kamayan meal for six people for only $68.95 I was sold. With the "Animan meal" you get Chicken or Pork Barbeque, Grilled Tilapia, Grilled Squid, Grilled Pork, Flitter Shrimp (which are deep fried shrimp in panko crumbs), Lumpias (Lumpiang Shanghai as they call them), Salted Egg, chopped up Mango, Tomato, Onion, Sweet Yams, three huge bowl-filled scoops of white rice, Steamed Broccoli and Eggplant. Served on a movable tray on top of that banana leaf, it was feast fit for a king. Most of food we tried was excellent, including the lumpias which were a crispy golden brown that paired nicely with the Vietnamese Sweet Chili Oil dipping sauce, the deep fried shrimp were fresh from the fryer, the pork was nicely seasoned, and the veggies were steamed warm, the tilapia was a little too salty even with the vinegar that you pair it with, and the squid was a little too overcooked and therefore a little tough. I loved the salted eggs (oddly enough because I thought they'd be too salty but they weren't for me) as it provided a nice balance with the diced mangoes, tomatoes and yams.

There was so much food all eight of us could have eaten this huge tray of food and been satisfied. But since we were here we had to try some of the staples of Filipino cuisine, like the Pancit Bihon which is rice stick noodles sauteed with chicken, celery, carrots and onions. I liked but didn't love this dish as it lacked in a little flavor for me. We also ordered the Sisig Baboy which had marinated grilled diced pork topped with chopped onion and jalapeno served on a sizzling skillet. The Lechon Kawali which is deep fried pork belly was fried to perfection and was accompanied by a special dipping sauce. And since our meal couldn't be complete without the traditional Halo Halo with shaved ice, scoops of ume ice cream, condensed milk and sweet beans. It was so weather was so hot around us that the ice literally melted before our eyes, but it still was a unique treat for me.

In the end, our bill literally came to twenty dollars a person, which for a meal for eight people was a real steal. One of my dining mates even inquired about how much they sold a batch of freshly deep fried lumpias for and managed to make a deal for a hundred lumpias to-go for only thirty dollars! Yet another example of a dining deal in a somewhat unkempt area of town. They only take cash, and they don't have their liquor license, so no booze to go with your large meal. But I'll be back with family members so they themselves can try for the first time the unique dishes of the Philippines at Pampanguena Cuisine.
author: Jason F.

description:
Thank you *very* much to Leah F. for finding a hidden "diamond" of a restaurant!!!  Who EVER knew that there would be a humble, simple yet DELICIOUS Filipino Kamayan-style restaurant in the Mission!  :)

Due to this discovery, I believe I've been here, at the least, 5 times!  

*EVIDENCE* that this restaurant has wonderfully comforting and good Filipino cuisine!  ;)

Ate Josie and Chef Michael have my continued support of this wonderful restaurant.  :)
author: Nan P.

description:
Super fun experience with your friends or family. 

I went with a party of 5 and we chose the 6 party portion. It was fun to try the different meats and sauces. Tomato and mango paired really well with everything! What BBQ isn't tasty? I appreciated the vegetables to balance heavy protein too.

 Fresh and beautiful presentation.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
I've tried Filipino cuisine a number of times, not my favorite because I find the dishes to be a bit too heavy. However, I'm still down to try dishes I've never had before & had been wanting to try out Pampaguena Cuisine given all of their rave reviews on yelp.

While the kamayan style dinner platters are definitely a better photo-opp & Instagram-worthy, we opted for more variety & ended up picking a few different dishes on the menu instead. We started off with the Lechon Kawali (crispy deep fried pork) -- it's pretty similar to the chicharrones you might find at Hispanic restaurants. Very crispy, moist chunks of pork. I wasn't a big fan of the tamarind based soup which I found a bit too sour for my taste. The Kare Kare (oxtail in peanut based sauce) was interesting, the peanut sauce is not too thick & the oxtail was very tender. Definitely a dish that goes well with a bowl of steamy white rice. We finished off the meal with Halo Halo.

The staff was friendly & helpful. Parking in the area is tricky, hit or miss. Cash only.
author: Ruby C.

description:
The Bay Area has no shortage of Filipino restaurants.   I think I've been to most of them.   Pampanguena is one of the best Filipino restaurants I've been to. It's on top of my list along with Kuya's in San Bruno.  

Eating here brings me back to my childhood in Manila.  Pampanga is a province of the Philippines known as the culinary capital of the country.  I grew up admiring Kapangpangans for their relationship with food and passion for cooking. 

The BBQ for six "kamayan" style is awesome.  It's a medley of grilled meats and seafood served on a banana leaf, meant to be eaten without utensils by everyone.   I especially enjoyed the squid, perfectly tender and not overly seasoned.  Very healthy portions (well, "healthy" as in generous not "healthy" as in healthy.  It's Filipino food, c'mon).

A few downgrades, not really about the food.  The restaurant is cold inside.  Plus don't go here if you're looking for a good looking restaurant with a nice ambiance.  It's not that nice inside.  And for some very strange reason, it's cash only.  I mean, are you kidding?  It's completely inconvenient.  TOTALLY RIDICULOUS.  Also, parking is a pain.  If you can withstand all of these non food related drabs, you'll enjoy the experience of good food. 

Finally, the proprietors are very lovely and friendly folks.  You can tell they take great pride in their food, just like kapangpangans.  I wish the very best for this restaurant and hope they continue to do well.  But for heaven's sake...Stop the ridiculous cash only  practice!
author: Angel S.

description:
Was in SF for a work conference, raised in SoCal, but now live in Hawaii.  There's a big Pilipina/o population there, but I haven't found a joint that does kamayan style.  So I yelled this spot up.  I was by myself but really wanted the kamayan, so I ordered the player for two.  Frankly, it looked like it could feed three.  The staff was extremely courteous and constantly checked up on me, maybe to make sure I didn't need to go to the hospital from the inevitable food comma.
  
Anyway, the meal was on point.  Massive amounts of BBQ chicken, pork, a whole fried tilapia, okra, steamed egg plant, broccoli, sliced mango, sliced tomato, and two salted egg.  Just for about 25 bucks.  The salted egg was the right consistency and flavorful without being overly salty.  It was probably the best salted egg I've had.  I love them to death, but with pre-hyper tension I gotta reduce the sodium intake.
author: Frederick M.

description:
Eating with your hands is such an organic way to feed oneself. There's something so satisfying about caving in to this oral fixation.  Then factor the smell of the banana leaves and rich aromas coming from the variety of fried goodness balanced out by veggies- what a way to experience Filipino cuisine! 
Josie is so  hospitable and genuine - you can tell that she enjoys cooking/serving her customers. I highly recommend Pampangueña for bigger parties - actually there is an option to  order a la carte. My buddy and I opted the kamayan style for 2- we were in disbelief when the food came- it looked like a platter for 4. Although more is never a problem as there's always take home. I especially enjoyed the mango with baggoong (shrimp paste)- great way to clean the palate. 
Tip- According to Josie - you can order ahead for dining-in to cut the wait time. It does take awhile to prepare all that food- no matter - TFC (The Filipino Channel) plays on the Teli- catch up to your Pinoy variety show and Telesera.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Sadly, they don't serve the silogs all day on weekends. The server recommended the binalots (meat, steamed rice, eggplant, grilled tomato, and salted egg). She let me sub in garlic rice for a $0.50 charge and it's worth it. I love garlic rice! It was my first time getting a binalot dish and I didn't really like the sides. My boyfriend liked the eggplant though. I got the sisig binalot and he got the bbq chicken binalot. The sisig was too salty and too spicy from the jalapeños but the flavors were really good. I was able to push aside most of the jalapeño pieces and the rice helped balance the saltiness so it was okay. I've had better sisig elsewhere. The bbq chicken was really good. I love the slightly sweet and charred smoky taste of Filipino bbq. 
I also tried the lumpia and it was okay. It wasn't piping hot so I feel like it might've been sitting out for a while. 
The service is super friendly, but the food is mediocre. Finding parking wasn't too difficult on a Saturday evening and there was no wait at the restaurant!
author: Emily L.

description: Came here after a long walk. The breakfast menu was available all day and costs $6.50 to $8.50.  They all had garlic rice which was flavorful and garlicky, two fried eggs and tomatoes.  Overall the food was decent, a nice place for a quick lunch.  Noticed the customers were all Filipino, that means the food is authentic.  Worth a visit, if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Expensive, but good. Went with my family. Probably won't come back. It looked nice online, but it was smaller and kind of dirty. Service is not that great. We were standing for a long time before realizing we just seat ourselves. They assumed we should know how it works there. For high dollar prices i expect high dollar service
author: Laura B.

description: So delicious!!! I love local joints like this and you can tell the people working there really cares about the food they put out. The only thing that was the downside was the squid was missing on our orders and the food was just too good for any of us to realized that was missing. With tax and tips, $20 per person and a full belly of yummy food. Come check this place out!
author: Sappho C.

description: Cheap, fresh and delicious with a family atmosphere and feeling. It somehow tastes better when you eat with your hands :)
author: Jasper P.

description: This was my first time going to this Filipino restaurant. I read from other reviews it's a mom and pop restaurant not too far from my house. It's a small restaurant with street parking and it is cash only. I met the owner and her daughter and they were so nice.  Their menu is pretty extensive with beef and pork dishes, seafood and soups. I was torn between the pork adobo and sinagang ng baboy which is a tamarind based broth. The owner herself recommended the sinagang so I went with that and I was surprised that it was a huge bowl for sharing. The broth was very tasty and you could taste the tamarind in it. It had chunks of broccoli, baboy, and some peppers in it. I definitely made 3 meals out of it. I also noticed the table by me had a spread on their table with palm leaves and their food wasnt on plates but on the palm leaves itself. She recommended me trying that next time, but I'll definitely need to share with my family since they are family size portions. All in all I'll definitely be back especially to try the pork adobo next!
author: Dianne E.

description:
3.5 stars. 

We ordered the platter for 2 people with lumpia, grilled tilapia, BBQ chicken, grilled pork, steamed broccoli, okra and eggplant. The lumpia are the best - it's fried spring rolls done Shanghai style, crispy and flavorful. and I liked the tilapia. But the steamed vegetables are flavorless and I didn't like the dish sauce that came with it. The grilled pork & BBQ chicken was a bit too salty for me. 

All in all, great value if you like the individual things within the platter. If I come back here, I would probably just order individual dishes given my taste preferences.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Food is good , some unusual ingredients on the classic filipino food. Like zucchini on the kare-kare and broccoli on the sinigang. Service is pretty slow. Cash only.
author: Kristina A.

description:
Food was super good! Home-cooked taste. It's really fun eating with your hands (or kamayan) when you're not in the Philippines, since it makes you feel right at home.

Their servings are quite good and the prices are reasonable --- we ordered the Tatluhan (good for three people) and we were able to finish it. Not too much and not too little.

The only tip I can give is that even though the store says it's open at 10, they open at 10:30-10:40.
author: Raine A.

description:
Authentic Filipino food that will wow your palate and stomach! Extremely friendly service too.

We shared the 2-people platter between 3 (hungry) females and it was the perfect amount. The platter was an assortment of carbs (2 bowls of white rice, mixed with diced mango, onion, and tomato), protein (grilled fish, BBQ pork and chicken), and fiber (broccoli, eggplant, and okra). I loved the variety and how each component complimented each other in the mouth. 

The service was one of the friendliest I've seen. The owner explained to us about the sauce, and how to mix the rice and diced mango/onion/tomato together. They really made sure that we are enjoying our dinning experience there. It makes me happy to see how passionate they are about this restaurant and the food. 

Affordable pricing. $12/person and we had no left over and did not feel gross from overeating. 

Plenty of street parking near by.
author: Wendy F.

description:
Service was prompt. We were immediately seated during our visit.  The server was very courteous and patient.  

Their food was so so.  It wasn't bad, but I wouldn't say spectacular, either.  It's a good place to get Filipino food if you're in the area. But I wouldn't purposely drive gete just to get my full of Filipino cuisine.
author: Rochelle 'Shella' T.

description: Came here and arrived at 6:15 pm. It says it closes at 7:00 pm and when I got here she said she doesn't accept ppl in after 6:30....it was barely 6:15!!! I was about to go HAM and order the whole damn menu and it was just 2 adults 1 child. I guess it's there loss because they could have made good money. But If you close at "7 pm" you need to honor that or let ppl know u actually close at fucking 6:14 pm on the dot. If you come here make sure it's like 5 hours before closing time to be safe.
author: Secret L.

description:
I finallyyyy made it here after drooling over the pics since I've arrived to the Bay Area (after it was featured on Yelp's ROTD). I must tell you, I love places like this - family-owned, big portions, food made with love, and no sticker shock. It's refreshing to pay $10-15 for a great meal served with warm hospitality. It's one of those family businesses that you cheer on because they are so warm to you. The service really made my day because they serve everything with a smile and welcome you to their restaurant like family! 

We ordered the family style meal for 2 (split between 3). It came with grilled fish, two piping hot bowls of rice, salted eggs that you mix with a mango/tomato/onion salad, lumpia, grilled pork, chicken, vegetables (I think I have it all?). Although to be completely honest, I don't think the Filipino food is up my alley, I do think if you enjoy it a lot, you would love the food here! 

Also, the place is super kitschy and cute. Karaoke, Filipino drama, and cute and adoringly tacky decorations on the wall, this place really stole my heart. :)
author: Cindy W.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Saturday with 2 other friends around 7:15 and was able to get seated immediately. The server told us they had been swamped up till then and that we came at a good time, so we got lucky!

Ordering food here was the simplest thing ever. We opened the menu, agreed on getting the 3 person platter, and that was that! I love how quick and painless it is here. Yes there are appetizers and entrees you can order a la carte, but since it was our first time here we wanted to get the platters that this place is known for.

On the platter there was:

Lumpia: the fried lumpia rolls were solid. There was enough for 2/3 per person

Fried shrimp: it wasn't as crispy as it could be but it had good flavor

BBQ chicken (or pork): the chicken was kind of fatty but other than that it was good

Fried fish: it's so interesting that they serve the whole fish fried. It was kind of hard to eat since it came with all the bones and I didn't have chopsticks to pick out some of the bigger bones (had to resort to using my hand instead), but other than that it was fine

Grilled pork: this wasn't my favorite as it felt just a little bit tough to eat, but there was a lot of flavor

Grilled squid: surprisingly good given that I don't like squid that much. It was on the salty side but this might have been my favorite meat on the platter

Salted eggs: these taste exactly like the salted eggs I grew up eating at home. I haven't had one of these in a looooong time so I was really happy the platter had them. To be fair, it was super salty so I had to eat a ton of rice with it, especially with the egg white, but it brought back many happy memories of eating them with my parents.

Steamed veggies: these were all kind of bland. I ate a couple pieces of the broccoli but didn't touch the eggplant or the okra

Rice: there was soooooo much white rice on the platter, portion-wise definitely more than a bowl per person. Good thing we were all pretty hungry!

At the end they gave us some sweet potatoes in a sweet syrup as dessert on the house. These were pretty good, but at this point I was pretty darn full so I only tried a piece or two.

Overall I really enjoyed the food and appreciated how much rice we were given to eat with everything. We demolished everything and only some of the veggies were left at the end, so if you come in hungry you can definitely finish the whole thing!

The food is 4 stars, and my last star is for the service. I loved our server who was really nice. I pointed out an oil stain on the table from the previous patrons, and he came over and scrubbed very furiously at the spot and apologized really nicely for missing the spot when he was wiping down the table earlier.

Parking is a pain in this area, watch out. I circled around for 5-10 minutes before I got lucky and saw this tiny street parking spot a block away from the restaurant. Definitely carpool if you are planning to come here with friends! I'm so glad we did.

Our total came out to $17 pp after tax and tip.
author: Dianna H.

description: Pretty good food, really friendly service, seems like a true Authentic Filipino place. Definitely probably better to come in a large group so you can order al ot and try a good variety. We only ordered the Sizzling sisig and the lechon kawali. Both super good and solid, crispy, yummy! Will definitely return.
author: Vivian D.

description:
4.5 Stars

The service here is excellent! They are super friendly and attentive. 

There were 7 of us so we ordered the kamayan animan (for 6 people), lechon kawali, relyenong talong and sisig bangus. We also ordered fresh coconut juice, calamansi, mango juice and guava juice. The juices were good; I liked that the coconut juice was serviced in a coconut. 

The food was delicious. Everything was brought out in a timely manner except it took a little longer for the sisig bangus to be served. The kamayan was more than enough for us; we had leftovers to take home. The kawali was meaty and tender. I pretty much only eat eggplant when it's prepared as talong, and this one was good. 

For dessert, we ordered halo halo and two leche flans. The leche flan was super, super creamy. So good!

Pampanguena is such a chill and casual place. Will definitely be back for the kamayan again.
author: Rose A.

description:
Hella food. 

So this Filipino restaurant was featured on YELP for an ROTD review and I quickly bookmarked the place. I was checking their photos and I began to salivate as I scrolled through them and I finagled the Wifey into eating here a week later on typical cool and foggy San Francisco day. It was a just before lunch time on a Saturday and parking along Mission Street is always a challenge, but we managed to find a spot across the street. 

First impression of the place was a typical Filipino joint with decorations that is fitting more for a seafood restaurant with a nautical theme of fish, lobsters, seahorse, dolphins, crabs and anchors adorning the walls. I don't know where they got these from, but it seems like they got them from a yard sale and just hung them up for decorations and they looked out of place against the bamboos and tropical thatch shingles that are more appropriate decorations, IMHO. However, nothing screams Filipino like Karaoke and they definitely had that. 

OK, we weren't here for the decorations and we were here to order their "Kamayan Style" dishes and they did not disappoint. We ordered the "Tatlohan" for three people and sat back and enjoyed looking at the other patrons' orders as they were delivered to their tables as the Kamayan was the popular way to go. Kamayan means to eat with your hands, and you certainly had that option as there is a sink just in front of the counter for you to wash your hands if you choose to do so, but they also offered utensils for those who didn't want to go commando. Hey, eating with your hands is one of the most natural things there is in this world. 

Upon receiving ours on a bed of beautiful banana leaf covered straw platter, I had to quickly take a photo and marvel at what was in front of us: A cornucopia of different types of Filipino food that was well balanced from different textures ranging from crunchy, crispy and chewy to flavors from savory, tangy, salty and sweet. We dug in like hungry teenagers just coming home from school and left no evidence behind that such a scene was committed. In other words, you won't be leaving hungry and be prepared for leftovers if you're a light eater. 

I also have to give props to the service since it was definitely exceptional. I don't know if he owns the place, but they guy with the mustache was one of the friendliest and happiest person I have ever met working in a restaurant as he surely made it an enjoyable experience. 

Like General Douglas MacArthur said to the Philippines during WWII, "I shall return."
author: John G.

description: If I wanted leftovers, I would have ate at home. This place was so gross, we poked at our food and couldn't wait to leave and eat something else to wash our pallet off. The food was not fresh, it was microwaved or thrown in the deep fryer to reheat. The taste was terrible. Service was bad and dirty.
author: Gloria T.

description:
Tip: Cash only!

Tasty food! good experience. Luckily we found a spot right in front of the restaurant, but parking in this area can sometimes be difficult.

I came here for lunch on a Sunday because it was nearby. The place was crowded so the service was a tad slow in taking our order. Otherwise, they were super friendly and explained how to mix the food to us. We ordered the 2 person platter for $27 with chicken bbq, and ordered an additional pork bbq skewer so we could try both. Great value for the size of the platter and will definitely be enough for two.

It came with fish, grilled pork, bbq chicken, veggies (okra, broccoli, and eggplant), diced tomatoes and mango, lumpia, two salty eggs, and rice. A big amount of food for two people but we easily finished it all....The lumpia was nice and crispy. The veggies and mango/tomato was okay. Excellent meat and dipping sauce. We were quite satisfied and will be coming back again.

Great, authentic food, and casual family style place.
author: Christina G.

description:
Come hungry - and come with people. There is a lot...and i mean a LOT of food.

I can only write a review for the Kamayan style dinner which is a set meal for 2, 4, or 6+ people. Basically they present you with a ginormous assortment of grilled chicken/pork, lumpia, a whole lot of vegetables, and fish as well as an assortment of sauces (or, what I would call crack sauce because it's SO good)

Service was pretty great too - I went once a few weeks back and when I came back, the owner/dude knew me as the guy who "asked for the secret sauce recipe".
author: Anthony L.

description:
First off the female greeter is hot
The steaks are not, but the kabobs will have you slapping your pop!!! Kabob Beef was tender and hot. The chicken was breast meat and juicy....love the basmati ricewill be back for the kabobs, not the steak!
author: Al T.

description: Went to Pampanguena Cuisine today for a birthday party and we had the kamayan. Everything was delicious. Authentic filipino food kamayan style (using your hands). It had everything - grilled squid, fried fish, BBQ chicken, salted egg, mango, tomato. YUM!!! I kept wanting to eat more but I know I shouldn't. The staff was also very attentive and friendly.
author: Glenn G.

description:
4.5 STARS

A group of friends had a joint birthday party last weekend. Since there was lots of liquor, we needed food. They decided to get some party trays for takeout from Pampanguena on Saturday, March 19th.

*Lumpiang Shanghai: CRISPY, DEEP FRIED PORK EGG ROLLS
*Pancit Bihon: STIR-FRIED RICE STICK NOODLES SAUTEED IN CHICKEN AND ENRICHED W/VEGETABLES
*Barbeque: GRILLED CHICKEN MARINATED WITH OUR SPECIAL SWEET AND TANGY SAUCE

The grilled chicken skewers were huge and so good! I ended up eating two of them over the course of the night. The chicken was moist and tender with a nice char. The sauce, savory with a sweet tang. I loved this dish! The pancit was lukewarm when I got there, so the noodle texture was slightly hard. The flavors were really mellow, but I wished I was there to try this dish hot. I love stir fried rice noodles. Since I wasn't eating red meat, I didn't try the lumpia. It was very tempting though. Everyone seemed to love them and it was the first item to go.

Their bbq item was delicious. I'd love to visit the actual restaurant to try more things. Especially now that I can have red meat. Give me lechon, lumpia, sisig and more! My mouths watering just thinking about it. Yum!
author: Elena N.

description:
A very chill and relaxing place to grab a bite to eat whether it be for lunch or dinner.

Came in today for dinner and had an amazing meal. 

Parking was easy but it can be very difficult to find around this particular area. Most of the parking is metered so be prepared to bring quarters or have a card on hand for the machines.

When you walk inside you see the seating to your left. There will probably be someone near the entrance as well to seat you and/or give you a menu as well. The servers here are very polite and gracious. They really seem to go out of their way to make sure you are attended to you. For that, I am very appreciative. 

After being seated I received a menu and everything looked amazing. They have a lot to choose from but I tend to be very consistent with what I like to eat at Filipino restaurant. Usually  I get adobo and bistek but today I decided to change it up!!! I decided to go with the Kaldereta and the sisig. It has been a long time since I last had either and figured why not be adventurous here, especially since the reviews are so good. Of course I had to get some lumpia as well because what would a Filipino meal be without lumpia!

After placing the order I waited patiently. As expected, there was a TV with Filipino broadcasting on, TFC (Sometimes you'll see GMA but that tends to be rare). This place wasn't too busy either. There was only one other group here when I arrived so I figured it would get busy later on. 

Be advised that this is a CASH only business so keep that in mind. There is an ATM located inside but it is currently not working so you will most likely have to go to the liquor store at the corner to get cash or stop by the bank before coming here. 

In regards to the food, everything tasted great. The lumpia was good. I liked that I could get a lot of pieces for so cheap. The sisig was OK but it seemed like there was more fat than meat but maybe I just being picky. The Kaldereta alright but it seemed like they might have put a lot of ketchup an tomato sauce in it to make it taste more flavorful. I did however like the peppers that they put in the Kaldereta, nice big pieces making it spicy!

My satisfaction with the meal is without a doubt FANTASTIC. But, getting a functioning ATM and/or becoming an business that can accept ATM and credit cards would make a big difference. I think I would come back to try the desserts here since I did not have enough room in my stomach after filling my belly. 

#salamat
author: Robert F.

description:
Josie and her team were able to make a special catering request to cater fresh made Halo Halo at
my wedding. They were very accommodating and easy to work with. Their halo halo gave our guests the taste of my Filipino culture and that was very important to me. Thank you and your family for being able to accommodate us. It was one of the highlights of our wedding. Our guests enjoyed one our finest homemade authentic Filipino desserts for the first time!!  The only downside was it was pretty pricey per halo halo. Other than that we have no regrets.
author: Kristine R.

description:
It was my first time going to a Filipino restaurant. There's usually none around in SoCal so once I got here, I needed to try it out. The family owned restaurant is so welcoming and friendly. Not only are they friendly, but the food is amazing and very traditional. It's crazy how much variety there are and everything is so filling. The food served my appetite well. 

This place is a must go type of restaurant. I loved everything about it. I would definitely come here again.
author: Don C.

description:
Let me start by saying that I would totally come back to this restaurant. I'm Filipino and I think I'm pretty freakin' picky when it comes to Filipino food so for me to say that I would come back says a lot. I've been looking for a good Filipino restaurant and I'm happy to say I've found one.

PROS:
The lechon kawali, fried pork, is delicious. It was my favorite dish and let me tell ya, I usually don't eat this stuff because it is a heart attack waiting to happen. But seriously, it is good and surprisingly, it didn't come out all hot so I was skeptical but the texture was crispy and tender on the inside. 

The garlic fried rice is good. I love love love garlic and the fried rice sure does have a wonderful and garlicky rich flavor.

The grilled bangus, milkfish, is also good. I ordered it with the diced tomatoes, onions, and mangoes on it and I think it would have been better without it.

CONS:
While we were eating, two homeless-like people came in and I guess wanted money or something. From what I remember, I was told they come in because the customers tend to give them money. One of them was this lady and I had to say out loud, "Excuse me" so one of the workers in the back could escort her out. If I would have waited a little bit longer to say excuse me, the stuff running down her noise may have dropped in our food. I know, ewww.

The Kare Kare, pork stew in peanut butter, was OK. It was more on the soupy side and I prefer the sauce more thick and heavy. 

Overall, it's a good Filipino restaurant and the service is excellent! 

PS. They got karaoke inside.
author: Loreto D.

description:
Came here ON A SUNDAY afternoon around 3pm. It was EMPTY. Place seemed decent. 
1- it is cash only 
2 we didn't wait I wanna say more than 15 mins for our food.
3-ordered the 3 serving and it was a plentiful amount of food that w head hella leftovers to take home. I mean maybe it's just how I eat but ya we had leftovers. 
4- food quality was ok. It wasn't great and it wasn't not great. It was just ok. I've ate kamayan style before and I think it taste wayyyy better. Like really I'm not hating on this place at all, the food just didn't have me feeling like "oh shit this is bomb"  so it was just ok. We didn't order any of the other food BUT the 3 serving so I'm only basing it off of what we ordered.
4 service was GREAT. No issues no nothing. Very helpful and always attentive. They even chopped it up with us for a bit which was nice since it was just is. And I never had to ask for anything. Like more water or napkins or anything like that. 

Why knock off one star only because they ONLY except cash and the kamayan style meal we had didn't AMAZE me.  But really. No hate on this place at all. I would come back here to try the other food AND would refer people to come here to try it themselves. I mean we all have different taste right.
author: Eliza O.

description:
I ate at Pampanguena to celebrate my brother's birthday the other week. We had reservations for 11 people and ordered the Kamayan style dinner for 4 and for 6. All the Kamayan style dinners come with the same items, just more or less of them depending on how many people it's supposed to serve.

The meals came and after scrambling to take a bunch of pictures, we finally dug in. Remember to mix up some rice, onions, mangos, tomatoes, and the salty egg! My favorite meat was probably the bbq pork. The sauces were also really good! They had the traditional vinegar (use for tilapia), shrimp paste (use with anything!!!), sweet chili (use for lumpia), and a sort of soy sauce-ish one (also good with anything!).

My family also ordered fried lechon and diniguan on the side. Both were delicious!!! I especially loved the fried lechon and the brown sauce... Mmm.. Tender meat with a crunchy outer crust!

Service was very friendly and accomodating to our large party. Pampanguena is definitely a fun place to bring your friends who have never tried Kamayan style Filipino food!
author: Tara A.

description:
Cash only folks, in the Excelsior district, spot is good, you can eat kamayan or regular, let me break down what we sampled and how it faired

Shanghai lumpia - standard short, piping hot

lechon kawali - deep fried pig skin, meat and fat how can you say no to this

sisig baboy (pork) - sizzling plate of pork with jalapenos and onions, missing the fried egg on the top, not one of my favorite dishes here, the meat tasted tad rubbery/old

kare kare (oxtail in peanut butter stew) - my measuring stick for most filipino dishes revolves around how well they can make this dish, here they made everything above par, heavy stew not watery, no extra seasoning needed (fish sauce, bagaoong), the string beans were super fresh they put them into the stew probably when they were bringing it out, made the string beans lil too fresh. the oxtail portion was decent, I would order this again

chicken adobo - standard, saucy, vinegary, not oily, heavy portions of chicken

for what they offer everything is good, I do recommend bringing 2 friends so you can sample more then just your regular silog plates

again cash only, atm inside

food **** everything was good, sisig was not my favorite
price $$
service **** friendly, helpful
ambiance *** clean, bambooish decor, if you order kamayan leaves on everything
author: Clarence A.

description: We've tried Kamayan Style and it's super good. I highly recommend this place! It was really fun experience with family/friends, good service and great place! We'll come back again.
author: Maeda L.

description: Lordy lord, where have you been all my life? OMG, if you havent tried pampanguena, you need to. This place is amazing and the food + service is on point. Basically in a nut shell, get the family style, Kamayan style dinner for either 2 people, 4, or 6 + folks and eat to your heart content. You will be presented with an assortment of grilled meats, lumpia, veggies, and fish to share among friends and family. The owner is so sweet and he encourages you to try everything. It's definitely different than what majority of the Filipino restaurants serve in the city. The owner emphasizes "healthy" eats. Take a look at the picture and do yourself a favor and just come here and come hungry. Also note, it's cash only :)
author: Diane T.

description: Josie and staff are the best! We always have them cater our parties at work and they have the best Filipino food in the city!
author: Loco Moco M.

description: So grateful to experience this wonderful restaurant in the outer mission. I had no issues making reservations the day before for a group of 8. We had a very warm greeting from the workers and we  were seated right away. I believe the owner took our order and he was very friendly and patient with us. We decided on the kamayan dinner and it exceeded beyond my expectation. It was very delicious and it was plenty of food for us. I especially love the presentation. The price was great $$ I think per person it was $20 a person and that's with gratuity. I highly recommend you experience this gem .. it's definitely worth it. Great food. Friendly service. Authentic Filipino experience.
author: Ahline C.

description: Food was good. Ambience is nice but place was ok. But will definitely come back for the food. Btw, sadly, it's CASH ONLY.
author: Love C.

description:
My husband and I went there for dinner last week. He's from Pampanga and loves to cook. He was not impressed with the authenticity of the food. I ordered (something "safe" for a mid-western American like me) barbecued pork skewers and streamed rice. I was impressed. It wasnt too sweet and was all lean meat. The portion of meat was impressive. Some of the best Filipino barbecue I've had. 

 After we got our bill, I found out they didn't take credit cards. The waitress pointed to this makeshift ATM machine in the corner of the restaurant. I reluctantly used it and returned to the table. As we sat there counting out money for a tip, a homeless man tapped on the window and pointed at me. I tried to ignore him until he walked into the restaurant and stood at our table asking for money. We got rather frustrated and just wanted him to go away. My husband gave him a couple bucks to get rid of him. I doubt this incident would have occurred if I could have used a card, as I doubt the pushy, fragrant man took credit cards.

Why would a business not take credit cards? Are they doing something shady and don't want a paper trail? Please don't blame credit card fees, everyone knows they exist and they just get passed on in the price you pay. Not carrying cash is not just convenient but SAFER. 

I don't know the city all that well but this didn't seem like a bad area. They need to hire a security guard and  get a credit card machine.
author: David B.

description:
My mom ordered the Kamayan for 2 and we were the only customers in the entire restaurant and it took nearly 40 minutes to put together? It was missing the fried lumpia and the lady said she was waiting for it to finish frying and that they'd bring it out ASAP so my mom and I started eating.. ready for the kicker?.. The cook was rushing to get the lumpia to us and as she was pouring them out of the frying basket, one fell on the floor... no big deal, it was just one piece.. BUT WAIT! There's more... the lady comes chasing after the loner lumpia that fell on the floor, PICKS it up and PUTS IT BACK ON OUR PLATTER!! Holy shitballs, you guys, I could not believe what I had just witnessed. 

Sorry to say but after being here numerous times, after that incident, I will not be returning.
author: Kat P.

description: We come here to try eating foods with our fingers. It's amazing,  delicious and tastes very good. I would recommend to others. Cash only.
author: Popoy G.

description:
Best Shanghai Lumpia in town!! 100 pieces for $27, great for parties and pot luck. 

Cash only!
author: Sam K.

description: Excellent Filipino food.  Family run, mother daughter, Aunt.  Fantastic service, attentive, you can see them getting regulars by name.  We got the platter for 3 and it fed 5 of us with leftovers.  Also got a side of lechon and sigsig.  All excellent and on point.  Garlic fried rice had the right balance of garlic and crunch.
author: Jing K.

description:
Another SF Adventure!  Joseph A. recommended this place to us and he was right!  We came early so we were the first customer.  Josie the owner greeted us and welcomed us to sit anywhere.  The restaurant had lobster, crab, and seahorse decorations.  While we waited for our food we watched the Filipino Channels. They also offer Kamayan and preset menu for groups.  

::Drinks::
I got fresh Coconut Juice, it was refreshing. 

::Food::
We got Bangsilog which comes with a boneless milkfish, garlic rice, two eggs, tomato and cucumber slices.  I thought the milkfish could be a little bigger.  The Sisigsilog also came with garlic rice, two eggs, tomato and cucumber slices.  The Sisig was topped with fresh onion and green pepper.  It didn't have crunchy pieces but it was still good.  We finished everything and the portion was just right. The only thing I would request for when I come back is the egg, I prefer it to be sunny side up.  

(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=hsbQervgaDUQT6tbaSlWLA&userid=NO5e0WtLAOYcjheLU6OEVg)

(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Zxt_Ib8b94PKUEZ8i5hdcQ&userid=NO5e0WtLAOYcjheLU6OEVg)

::Customer Service::
Josie was very attentive and friendly.  She even took the time to chat with us for a little bit. 

::Rating::
I would come back here again. Customer Service was great and we enjoyed our food.  Overall, 3.5 Stars and rounding it to 4. 

::Tip::
Free WIFI just ask for the password

::M's Notes::
-ATM Machine 
-Street Parking
-Indoor Seating
-Catering Available
author: MarVy S.

description:
Generally I would not give 5 stars to restaurant that had a broken credit card and ATM machine, and didn't have the first item I ordered (Adobo Chicken), but everything else made up for it.

I had just moved to the neighborhood and after some initial unpacking, I needed to grab a late lunch. I had already gone north into Glen Park, so decided this time to head south to Excelsior. Very conveniently or dangerously, one of the closest restaurants to me is Pampanguena Cuisine. Growing up in Miami, there isn't a large Filipino population. And while I was friends with many at UCF in Orlando, there weren't real restaurants to go to. Since moving out here, any time I have the option to eat Filipino, I go for it.

I walked in to a table of four finishing off their family plate, and a few other tables with people. The nice waitress quickly got me seated while she was doing three other jobs. Looking over the menu was tough - a lot of seafood options, some standout pork, chicken, and beef dishes, and plenty of noodles. But as I was tired due to moving, I wanted to go simple - adobo chicken and meat lumpiang. 

This is when if it were another restaurant, it would be lower stars - first I was told they didn't have any adobo chicken left. But they did have pork, and like I'm going to turn down pork? Next was their card reader was broken. I did try their ATM, but that didn't work either, so had to run down to the donut shop (speaking of which, I should head down there this morning) and get cash. 

When I came back in, a Filipino couple joked "Had to get your fix?" We talked for a bit and they told me what they had ordered - the beef stew and the boneless bangus, and had loved both. Some things to try next time!

As for my order: the Lumpiang were really good, nice and crispy with a tasty filling. For the money they give you a lot, and it took a lot of willpower to save half for dinner. My main meal was the adobo pork. Delicious. A good mix of meaty and some slightly fatty bits, and the sauce had the perfect amount of vinegar. While I did have half for dinner, it was tough not licking the plate clean.

Before I finished a regular party came in, and instantly ordered the family meal for 6. The great waitress suggested I stick around and check it out, as did the owner/chef who came out to talk to the family. When it was brought out, I was impressed and liked that the owner told me to take a picture. She either knew I was a Yelper, or was really proud of her creation. Regardless, I now want to get a group together to eat it ourselves.

Speaking of the picture, I posted it to Facebook and all my Filipino friends back in Florida raved about it. The second they saw the banana leaf, they knew it was legit, and when I told them that silverware was optional, they were jealous.
author: Michael C.

description:
I've been searching for a place that has really good sisig & unfortunately after trying to place, I'm still on the hunt for that. 

I got the sizzling sisig and it was good but there wasn't any wow factor to it. The pork was a little dry and not tender or moist at all. It wasn't the traditional sisig. I did like the onions and jalapeños  on it which gave it a nice kick. 

This place is *CASH ONLY* but they do have a ATM inside which I won't count on. My BF went to get cash from that very old ATM machine and no money came out!! The funds has been drawn out from his account as well. So we told the lady that worked there which I assume is the owner, and she accused my BF of having no money in his account. *insert rolling eyes emoji here* Good thing we were only missing a few bucks and found cash in his car. 

At first we wanted to come back to try the kamayan but after that incident & the food being just average, we probably won't be coming back.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
My first Filipino meal! After a coworker of mine brought some tasty lumpia to work, I was hooked! I have bookmarked Pampanguena for awhile and while searching for a Filipino restaurant on Yelp, this popped up.  

Got there early so there's no line and I was lucky to find a parking space just right across the street.  

I am guessing it's the owner and the owner's wife that's serving us and they were so very friendly.  Told the owner it was our first time having Filipino meal and he explained to us how to eat and what the food was.  Very down to earth and made us feel right at home.  

They use banana leave as plate and we were told traditionally food is eaten with the hands.  He also provided some silverware for those who aren't accustomed to the traditional way of eating with hands. 

We ordered a two person platter and an order of 20 piece lumpia.  The lumpia came out freshly fried and pipping hot, just perfect.  The platter looked like a feast and came with a variety of dishes including pork, chicken, whole grilled tilapia fish, rice, mango/tomatoes/salty egg salad, and lumpia.  I devoured the entire fish including the fish head, it's that good! 

They also gave us complimentary pickles and sweet yams to try.  Very simple but yet very tasty!

An excellent local family owned business that deserves 5 stars!
author: Shirley H.

description:
Finally got to try this place and do kamayan style for our holiday get together (12 people.)

Food = Great. 

Animan kamayan meal (says for 6 guests--IMO, could be 7 or 8 people) comprises of pork (or chicken) BBQ, grilled tilapia, grilled squid, grilled pork, flitter shrimp, salted egg, lumpiang shanghai, mango/tomato/onion, sweet yam/steamed rice, steamed seasonal vegetables, & steamed eggplant) = excellent. The various cuts of meat had delicious flavors, not dry; perfectly cooked fish, squid and excellent sides. The seasonal vegetables were okra, and they were ever so good (perfectly cooked and not slimy.) $68.95 x2

Sinigang hipon (traditional shrimp and vegetable soup (tamarind base)) = tangy, clear broth, and perfect with all of the food. $12.95

Lechon kawali (deep fried crispy pork) = delicious, crunchy and I took home the leftovers.  $12.95 x2

Chicken silog = one of the lunch companions couldn't resist the fried egg, chicken combination and had to get it. $8.50

Hot tea = $1.25 x7
Guava juice = $2.95 x1
Calamansi juice = $2.95 x3
Coke = $1.25

Service = super friendly, polite and efficient. 

Prices = reasonable to moderate. Total lunch for 12 with plenty of leftovers came out to $229.52. BTW, bring cash as they accept only cash.  (They do have an ATM inside.)

Thanks for taking care of us and not shoving us out after 2 hours of eating and chatting! And for taking our picture outside! We'll be back.
author: Fannie S.

description: This place was delicious! Their service was on point! I usually don't think much of Filipino restaurants since we can make and eat these same foods at our own home but this spot was  worth driving all the way from Hercules from! Their kamayan style 6 person meal was able to feed 8 people in my family and then some! Everything wasn't too salty or greasy which can happen sometimes for Filipino restaurants but this place had all the right flavors! Already planning our next trip back!
author: Krizta R.

description:
Food is delicious. Just wish the service was a little better. I get that you may be hungry and want to eat during your shift but at least dont ignore us when were the ones hungry as well.

Another occasion we were given attitude when i asked for utensils. I come here for the food, not the experience :)
author: Marvin R.

description: Came here to attend a family graduation reception lunch. The food was really good, and plentiful. Lots of choices were served, most of the food was served boodle style. Some of the other saucy dishes were served separately. Service was very attentive. Food was really good. I would recommend this place to anyone who likes Filipino food.
author: Daniel S.

description: Excellent food! Thank you, Tita Josie for cooking yummy food for our son's 1st birthday party!
author: Leslie G.

description: Ordered Kare-Kare, Bangsilog, Pork Sisig for pick up. I live around the neighborhood so parking wasn't a problem. Food is meh my kapampangan lola didn't approve(Emanyaman, maputla, malanyo, balamu palabuk sabo - kare kare, ditak pong mal) , she said Boracay grill has better kare-kare, and sisig. Portions are definitely on the small side fore sure. Bangsilog was puny. Superstar has better portion and has more buck for the money. 3 dish $40 not satisfied at all.
author: Clyde E.

description: So excited to try this restaurant. Drove from El Cerrito with family on Saturday and arrived at 2 pm just to find out they were closed. Yelp said they were open until 9pm. Disappointed.
author: Rosalinda R.

description: First time actually coming to this place because we wanted to bring lumpias to a house warming party so I went on yelp and I found this place.  We ordered 100 lumpias to go and it took about a good 10-15 minutes and the girl server there at the time was really informative.  We were actually hungry too so we got this rice plate to go with pork and it was BOMBBBBB.  we were so hungry we decided to eat a couple bites before heading out.  We were one of the last ones to arrive at the party and the lumpias were the first dish devoured.  SO GOOD. I definitely will come back to try out their other foods.
author: Ben Z.

description:
This place is such a gem! I think this was actually my first time trying Filipino food, and I loved how authentic the whole experience was. My friend and I came here for an early lunch on a weekday (around 11:30am), and we were the only ones there until like 12:30pm. I'm not sure how crowded this place gets, but it seems like you definitely won't have to wait for a weekday lunch. 

We decided to get the 2-person platter, and omg it was so much food. I think it could easily feed 3 people. All the food comes out at once, laid out on a giant banana leaf. Each person also gets their own banana leaf plate thing. Our waiter took the time to explain each food item to us--what it was, what sauce to use, etc. He also encouraged us to eat with our hands (the traditional way). It definitely felt weird at first, but once you get used to it, it's actually quite fun. The platter features quite a few items: lumpia, salted eggs, eggplant, okra, rice, chicken, pork, broccoli, diced papaya/onion/tomato mix, and a whole fish. LOTS of food. But everything was so good!! The salted eggs tasted a bit weird to me...but I think it's an acquired taste. My favorites were definitely the meats. The chicken was fantastic--loved the sauce they used. The pork was great. Both had so much flavor! And the fish, although a bit difficult to eat, was delicious! 

At $26, this platter is a steal! The food is fantastic and it's a wonderful dining experience. Any questions that you have--the workers here will be happy to answer. They seem very passionate about sharing their Filipino culture, especially through the food...and their enthusiasm made the experience that much better! Come here with an open mind, an empty stomach, and CASH (this place is cash-only). I will definitely be back!
author: Ashley Y.

description: Philippine favorites served picnic style on banana leaves.  Enjoyed the "kamayan" dining experience.  Tableware was available but eating with your fingers was encouraged.
author: Carmel C.

description:
Had the apattan kamayan set. Everything was good, and edible. I especially liked the fried shrimp and halo halo they made. I wish the set came with lechon tho, and the chicken had some type of teriyaki sauce I didn't like. 

Downside, restrooms were "out-of-order". Yes, we could wash our hands for the kamayan food, but we had to run across the street to the library to use their restroom.....
author: Jac T.

description: The menu is small but everything meals delicious. Good place for friends to get authentic food. But price is average.
author: Bennett M.

description: Went here for my mom's birthday, made a reservation to ensure that we would get a seat and there were plenty! I arrived there first, on time for the reservation, but my parents were super late since parking is really tough in this area. Anyways, the staff was so nice in getting everything ready and being patient with us, especially since it was approaching their closing time. The food was delicious, you eat it kamayan style, with your hands on banana leaves, very traditional! Soooo much food we had to take some home! This place is great for groups, they have menus that cater to both large and small groups. There is a karaoke machine constantly going so it does get noisy, but what do you expect from us Filipinos? We love to sing! Everyone should visit to experience traditional Filipino dining :)
author: Larissa L.

description: It's nice to eat with your hands every now and then. The food was so good and this was such a great experience eating with a group of friends. My favorite was the BBQ pork and fried octopus. Looking for an opportunity to come back!
author: Lynn M.

description:
This place gets the SFDives seal of approval - in my ever so humble opinion;)

Linoleum floor circa 1960?  Check

Formica tables circa 1980?  Check

Cash ONLY?   Check

Amazing Food?  Check
author: E R.

description: Sinigang was good! I didn't like the Bistek (beef steak tagalog) though, it was too salty and for a pampanguena, I don't think their Beef Steak Tagalog was the Pampanguena version. It's more like Batangas (or south-like) version instead of the way someone from Pampanga would cook it. But overall, I enjoyed it.
author: Angel M.

description:
Gave this place a try a few years ago, and I'd say it's probably one of the Filipino places we've enjoyed the most. The only reason we haven't been back more regularly is because the street parking can be so incredibly hit or miss, which can be a big consideration when you live in the city.

That said, the menu contains all the usual suspects you'd expect to find at any Filipino place, but it's not set up in the common turo-turo style - you order your entrees and your sides, and they are served to you properly, like at any other sit down restaurant. The owner asked us if we wanted to try kamayan style, but since it was our first time there, and I didn't know if my Irish/German hubs was up to that kind of adventure, we skipped it. Definitely want to try that out when we go back though.

All these other great reviews remind me of why we gave this place a chance to begin with. Going to make it a point to come back one of these next weekends. They do a nice job here.
author: Rod V.

description:
I ordered for pick-up so I can't review for their sit-down service but the food was really good. My favorite Filipino dish is Kare Kare and Pampanguena Cuisine's is definitely THE best I've ever had. The other dishes were great too: Sinigang, Pancit Bihon, Veggie Lumpia, and the Chicken Adobo. I plan on stopping by again sometime soon!

Another tip, this restaurant is CASH ONLY.
author: A. C.

description:
Casual, no frills place with delicious food. Also good for party trays / large catering orders. Great value for price paid in both quantity and quality. 

Dine In - 5 stars for food, 5 stars for service. Minus on star for no real ambience, tables and chairs were pretty old, and parking was impossible.

Catering - 5 stars for food (taste, quantity and presentation), 0 stars for packaging

Researched places to cater a filipino brunch and picked Pampanguena based on combination of Yelp reviews and pricing.

We came first to try it out for dinner on a Sunday night and parked about two blocks away. We were early (about 5pm) and were the only ones there but as we were eating saw multiple people come in for take out/catering orders and by the time we left a few more tables had filled up. Servers were friendly and attentive and food came out relatively quickly. We had the longsilog and lechon kawali, both were delicious and very good size portions. 

We subsequently placed a large catering order and the woman was very helpful with suggestions and portions. When we came to pick up, the food was ready on time. For 20-25 people we ordered 5 half trays of pancit, lumpia, sisig, chicken adobo and longganisa. Was plenty of food and we probably could have easily fed 40-45 people. Sisig and longganisa were the highlights. Pancit and lumpia were also very good. Chicken adobo was okay and was the one tray that was barely touched. Loved that the sisig and pancit were nicely arranged and garnished. 

Some tips for picking up large catering orders. 
- Call ahead when you are almost there so they can start taking the food out of the warming boxes and putting into cardboard carry trays
- Come with at least 2 people. Parking was impossible both Sunday around 5pm and Saturday around 11am so we needed to double park while one person ran into to get the food
- They are very generous with portions which is amazing but also makes the trays unstackable so either bring extra people or be prepared to make multiple trips back and forth to the car
- Bring large garbage bags to put the trays in before you carry and/or put in your car. The packaging was horrible (just one piece of foil placed loosely over the top that barely covers the entire tray and does not stay in place). We were extremely careful and everything still got everywhere. The longginisa in particular came in a try full of hot oil/grease that ruined a favorite hoodie and led to a pretty expensive interior car detailing
author: Sarina Y.

description: First time here and everything we ordered was expertly prepared and the service was prompt, professional and friendly. We ordered diniguan (pork blood stew) 5 stars perfect balance of vinegar. We also ordered lumpia which was crispy and not at all greasy. We also had longanisa (sweet pork breakfast sausage) with garlic rice and vinegar. The best thing we had was the crispy pork belly. Needless to say this is one of the most authentic and best filipino restaurants in SF. don't sleep on this one
author: Daren B.

description: Best Filipino food I've had. Fresh, non-greasy, delicious. Ten of us shared the family style feast and were all stuffed and happy without feeling heavy.
author: Redloci R.

description:
Came with the hubby two days before Xmas, only to be told they were closed for catering orders. The sign still said open as did their hours so we had explained to them we traveled kind of far on a friends recommendation. 

The lady who owned it and her daughter, despite being super busy, were ever so gracious and polite to allow us to dine in. We really did feel bad but at the same time we did drive all the way to the excelsior and risked parking in a really bad area to eat here.
